docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Hillary Rodham Clinton's optimism on new Federal support for children's health care (Op-Ed, Aug. 5) reveals with regrettable clarity all that is wrong in public policy debates today. Politically, the President mouths the words ''the era of big government is over,'' and then blithely works to spread its tentacles further into the lives of citizens. The Republicans meekly acquiesce, unable to articulate any principled opposition to the nanny state.

headline.main: Health Care Law Shows Big Government Lives

docs.abstract: Prof Richard A Epstein letter says Hillary Clinton's optimism on new Federal support for children's health care reveals all that is wrong with 'nanny state,' and ignores costs of heavy regulation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the New York State Legislature sleepily stumbled to the close of its 220th session at 3:40 P.M. on Aug. 4, party leaders in both houses rose to give valedictories expressing their abiding affection for their staffs, their colleagues, even their opponents. What they failed to mention were the nerve-jangling confrontations, the harsh invective and the simmering distrust that had been the session's real trademarks. This was not merely one of the Legislature's longest sessions ever -- 210 days, or seven months -- but also among its most contentious and least productive in recent years.

headline.main: Summary of Major Actions in the 220th Session of the Legislature

docs.lead_paragraph: When Gov. Pete Wilson presented his plan earlier this year to overhaul the biggest welfare program in the country, it seemed destined to redefine California as one of the least sympathetic states to which a poor person could turn for help. Adults who failed to find a job were to be cut off from aid after a year, half the time the Federal Government allowed. Mothers who did not help identify the fathers of their children would, under the proposal, get no aid at all. Women who could not care for their children would have adoption suggested as an alternative.

headline.main: New California Welfare Law: Pragmatism Tempers Cuts

docs.abstract: Harsh provisions of California's new welfare law have been tempered by pragmatism; while law will embrace notion of work first, and will leave many parents who combine welfare and work with somewhat less than they take home under existing law, it will also acknowledge that for most beneficiaries, passage from entitlement to employment requires much more than avaliable job; provisions discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A decade has passed since Kelly Stafford walked through the doors of the Brookhaven Psychiatric Pavillion here. But for her, the nightmarish days that followed are fixed forever. She had agreed as a 17-year-old to enter the hospital, expecting a brief respite from troubled family relationships. But once the doors closed, Ms. Stafford said, she remained inside for 309 days, many of them behind blackened windows in cruel darkness.

headline.main: Tenet Healthcare Tries to Settle Some Old Accounts

docs.abstract: As managed care companies move into area of mental health, many psychiatrists fear patients are being overlooked by organizations eager to scrimp on insurance costs; doctors say seriously ill patients are often discharged from mental health units after just few days, trapping them in cycle of hospitalization, relapse and hospitalization; managed care companies defend practice as reigning in undisciplined and wasteful spending on mental health care, where it is often hard to measure extent of patient's progress; payment by Tenet Healthcare Corp, which changed its named from Medical Enterprises, of $100 million to settle 700 claims of mistreatment by former psychiatric patients in Texas discussed; mental health care professionals say company came to symbolize excesses of era when corporate thirst for insurance dollars overrode patients' needs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1982, when the International Brotherhood of Teamsters first agreed to a lower pay scale for part-time workers at United Parcel Service, recently hired part-timers earned $9 an hour, or just $4 less than a full-timer with the same tenure. Today, the part-timers, mostly people who sort packages, still earn $9 an hour while full-timers, mainly the men and women in brown who drive U.P.S. delivery trucks, earn nearly $20. That sort of eye-catching shift helps to explain why the strike of 185,000 U.P.S. workers, which began on Monday, is a billboard reminder of how far the country has moved toward two tiers of jobs, one with much higher pay and more benefits than the other. Part-timers, temporary workers and contract workers populate much of the lower tier.

headline.main: Strike Points to Inequality in 2-Tier Job Market

docs.abstract: Part-timers at United Parcel Service have earned $9 an hour since 1982, while full-timers have seen their salaries raised from $13 an hour to $20 an hour since 1982; that is why strike of UPS workers is billboard reminder of how far country has moved toward two tiers of jobs, one with much higher pay and more benefits than other; part-timers, temporary workers and contract workers populate much of lower tier; question is whether it is possible, at UPS but also nationally, to narrow spread in wages, benefits and job status that has developed since 1960's; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Adopting drastic changes in the way it does business, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has begun transforming itself into a company far different from the one that upended the once-sleepy hospital world over the last nine years. Gone -- apparently -- is the obsession with 15 percent profit growth each year that at times may have led managers to actions that prompted a sweeping criminal investigation. Gone is the seemingly insatiable appetite for acquiring competing hospitals that has made Columbia one of the most feared participants in the health care industry. And gone is the once unshakable faith that to succeed in the modern health care system, a company must own businesses that provide every phase of treatment, from hospital care to home care.

headline.main: A Makeover May Change More Than Columbia

docs.abstract: News analysis: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp is transforming itself into company far different from one that upended once-sleepy hospital world over past nine years by abandoning or altering many controversial business practices; adoption of drastic changes in way it does business could well affect other parts of health care industry (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed legislation yesterday giving users of managed-care programs certain protections that consumer organizations described as the strongest in the nation. Under the new law, companies will be barred from giving financial incentives to doctors for limiting treatment, and they will be required to offer members the option of paying extra to select their own doctors. New Jersey is the first state to provide these protections to its three million managed-care subscribers, said Anthony Wright, the program director for New Jersey Citizen Action, an advocacy group.
